transcription.text: [ Music ]
Okay. So this is a quick talk and hopefully a demo at the end on Whisper.
Hands up if you've heard of Whisper.
Almost everybody.
So the first question to answer is why you have Whisper at all, when we've got the blockchain.
The blockchain allows people to communicate.
We can just make contracts.
We can send transactions to contracts.
They can be like messages.
The main obvious answer is that it's really expensive.
If you use the blockchain to communicate with each other, then you're paying essentially
to have everybody else know about and archive all of those communications.
Minor answers also include, hey, it's open and maybe we don't want everybody else to know
about what we're saying.
But of course that can be achieved with encryption.
So in essence, there are aspects of decentralized application building where we don't need consensus.
We don't want consensus.
What we actually want to do is simply do peer-to-peer communication.
So within the framework of doing massively multi-user applications, which when I say
massively multi-user applications, basically what I'm talking about are web apps, but also
these days decentralized applications too.
We see three main paradigms for communication.
The first is static publication, so where we publish generally quite a lot of data.
And it doesn't change.
It's the assets of a web page.
It's the text of a story.
It sort of goes up there.
It's maybe a movie.
It goes up there.
It stays the same.
This is stuff that we already have pretty decent p2p tools for.
BitTorrent, IPFS, and potentially even like FTP.
We also see obvious sort of peer-to-peer communication strategies where it's point-to-point, right?
So it's where I want to connect to one particular other identity and I want to feed them information.
So when we think of this, we think of things like Skype, Voice over IP, real-time communications.
That's generally where we're headed in that direction when it's point-to-point.
The final one is much more interesting than these two.
The final one is transient data grams is what I've called them, but this is the kind of
communication where we want to generally tell a group of people something for some
limited period of time.
So this is something that we don't really have a proper abstraction for yet, but you see it
every day.
You see it when you use an exchange.
When you use an exchange, you want to communicate to a bunch of people, generally the people,
the other people on the exchange, or the people at least on the exchange that want to change
a particular currency.
You want to tell them a particular message and you want that message to run out after
a particular period of time.
So transient messages between groups of people.
You also see them in things like Twitter, right?
When I use a hashtag, I'm actually trying to reference a group of people who might be
interested in something that I'm saying.
I don't want to reference everybody, so it's not like publication exactly, but a group of
people and for a particular period.
We can see some of the patterns within these massively multi-user applications.
In terms of direction.
When we send email, it tends to come from a particular identity.
It tends to go to a particular identity.
When we use things like mailing lists or use net, we're going to a multitude of identities,
but it's still coming from one.
When we use, there is also a notion of global stuff where it's not really coming from
anybody, maybe it's an anonymous publication, but it's going to a whole bunch of people.
Content, we already have answers for that.
Real-time communication.
In some sense, we have an answer for that within the Ethereum framework using the dev
p2b stuff, maybe a raw connection over that.
But for the final paradigm, that's basically what WISP is designed to address.
So in terms of privacy, I think it's also important to remember that -- and we probably
know this much more than when I first authored this talk, but it's very important to remember
that the metadata of the communications can often be almost as important to keep secret
as the content of the communications themselves.
So we have a notion that metadata collection actually gives very useful information on
what's going on.
So if we want privacy, it's important to make sure that the routing itself is kept
private as well as the content.
So what does WISP -- what actually is WISP?
So it's a bit of an odd thing because it's not a messaging system, so we don't deal
as being a pure point-to-point system for messaging, but it's also not a DHT either.
It's kind of a hybrid between the two.
It has a couple of additional attributes.
It has probabilistic message forwarding, which means the routing itself is kept private.
It's kept private because actually there's no easy way of doing any analysis on it since
it's probabilistic.
It's also oddly oriented around subject key.
So I'll show you later, but basically messages -- normally when we consider messages, they
have a very particular two endpoints.
They have the endpoint at the start, the endpoint that they eventually arrive at.
But within WISP, that's actually played down.
It's not a major part of the system.
Rather, the messages have a couple of attributes that are very important.
One of them are topics, right?
So there's a notion that messages have associated topics, and it's these topics that are used
to route the messages through the system.
I'll come on to that in a second.
So is it a DHT?
Well, if we think of it in terms of a DHT, then it's multi-key, which is to say messages
may have more than one key.
These are the topics that I alluded to earlier.
It's multi-value, which is to say topics or messages that have the same keys.
Actually, they can be different values associated to them.
And it's transient, so they don't stick around forever.
They have an explicit expiry.
If we think of it in terms of a data gram transport layer, then -- which we can do,
then it's also got some interesting attributes.
It is inherently multicast, which is kind of interesting.
It allows for actually reasonably efficient dealing with things like hashtags on Twitter.
And it's asynchronous.
So the messages -- the two points from which the message is go between don't actually have
to be online at the same time.
It's also got a nice little sort of in-built anti-doss system.
It's not next generation, but basically it's got -- we've got some good behavior incentivization
in there.
One of the important sort of tenets that WISPA's designed around is always considering identity,
a never-considering endpoint.
We consider endpoint to be basically an implementation detail to do with the hardware that it's
actually running on.
And it's as such, it fits a layer below this particular protocol.
In terms of WISPA, we never deal with the endpoints.
This is nice because it has certain -- it ties into the privacy thing.
If you never deal with endpoints, then in principle messages can never be tied to any
particular physical location rather than tied to cryptographic identities.
And that's quite an interesting attribute to have.
Furthermore, the implementation is configurable in terms of what trade-off the user, or perhaps
even the application wants from efficiency and privacy.
So on the one hand, if we want a lot of efficiency, we're going to have to give up some privacy
because we're necessarily going to be closer to the metal in terms of rooting the packets.
Similarly, if we don't want a vast amount of privacy, then we'll be able to trade that
off and get substantially faster transmission times.
It's topic-based, which means when we want to communicate within WISPA, we do so by
naming -- by associating topics which are small cryptographic identifiers with messages.
In order to eventually rein in these messages, which we may be interested in, we use the
same mechanism.
We use these small cryptographic identifiers.
In terms of the encryption it uses, the difference between a unique -- a unique
message within WISPA and a broadcast message within WISPA is essentially the difference
in which key it's encrypted with, right?
So we're not doing anything in terms of the sort of hardware close to the metal
routing with this.
What we're doing is saying, right, if it's a unique, I'm going to encrypt it with your
identity, which means, does it matter who receives it?
We want everybody to receive it in principle.
The only person who can actually decrypt it is the recipient.
With broadcast, rather than encrypting it with a particular identity, we encrypt it with
a particular message.
However, one of the nice things that's tied into this is the notion of rooted
in iability, which is if I'm merely storing a message or passing it on and I was never
interested in these topics, I will not be able to decrypt the message because I'm only
dealing with what is essentially a partial topic, a small portion of this topic, which
is sufficient for routing but not sufficient for actually decryption of the message itself.
Messages are authenticated as well.
The difference between there being an origin, so it coming from a particular identity and
it being anonymous, is simply the difference between it containing a signature and not
containing a signature.
This ties into a PGP with email when you can sign a message, encrypt a message or you
can encrypt and sign a message.
It's not a kind of idea except it's built into the protocol.
It's important to also get across what whisper isn't.
There's a bunch of stuff which it's definitely not suited for.
It's not suited for high bandwidth point-to-point transmissions.
Don't think you're going to do Skype over whisper.
It's not particularly suited to low latency transmissions, although it can be traded off
to some degree.
This isn't an application level protocol, so you're not going to use whisper directly in
order to take part in a chat room.
Application is going to be built on this.
It's not connection-oriented.
This is entirely about data gram messaging.
There are two routes in whisper to routing itself.
One is passive, which is essentially a case of gathering nodes that tend to pass you the
right messages.
This is something that's on the roadmap to being implemented in the
DFP2P protocol.
The second one is active routing.
This is essentially where we form what I call topic vortices.
I advertise that I'm interested in these particular topics, technically partial topics,
and my peers pass on messages to me, and they select messages.
They also pass on to their peers the messages that I'm interested in, although because
obviously it's an exponential trade-off, it does so at a relatively lower accuracy level.
In terms of forwarding messages, we have this notion of serving one's friends well.
We want them to stay our peers in general.
We don't want them to go away.
We want to behave well.
We want to give them stuff they're interested in.
There are three basic ways of determining this within the whisper protocol.
One is interesting topics.
The topics that we've already told them, hey, we're interested in this stuff.
You should pass on messages that actually conform to this.
Another is the lowest time to live.
We want to prioritize messages that are actually urgent.
The third is the highest proof of work.
Each message has an associated proof of work, which basically similar sort of thing to the
blockchain.
It associates a particular amount of computation to this particular message.
The way that we tell our peers about messages that we are interested in, topics that we're
interested in, is using this sort of masking, filtering approach.
You actually use bloom filters.
We pass the bloom filters to our peers.
Then they can test to see whether particular messages match these bloom filters.
If they do, they can send on to us.
They can combine bloom filters and send on to their peers so that their peers tend to give
them messages that we can then we may then be interested in.
This kind of filtering can be customized potentially per peer or even per application.
So the applications that may have very sensitive topics, we tend not to advertise to
our peers.
Applications that are not sensitive at all but actually do need to have much more real-time
characteristics, for example, maybe an exchange application.
They would sort of be much more aggressive in telling their peers what it is that they're
interested in.
I'll go into that a little later.
The API has three functions.
It's super simple, right?
It's now filter.
Post just sets a message off onto the network and the filter is able to set up filters and
check to see which messages have already arrived.
There's an example of new identity.
It's pretty simple.
You get a key back.
There's an example of post.
This is a bit more interesting.
It's a bit odd to have an optional from.
Normally as part of an API, we don't get the automatic ability to anonymize our messages.
This one does.
It's also got a two.
We can actually do a broadcast right from within here.
That means comparatively little because we have topics to identify the sorts of things
that this message is going to contain which then allows the potential recipients to identify
this from all of the various other broadcast messages.
We have the payload.
That's simply a bunch of data.
That's the actual body of the message.
A couple of other things, priority, which is the amount of work we're going to put in.
Therefore, that's going to alter how likely it is other nodes to pass on this message sooner.
A time to live, which essentially is the expiry date for the message.
Watch.
Again, this is filter.
You'll see that later.
Optionally has a two.
This is very interesting.
We don't automatically -- we're not automatically able to filter on the recipient of the message.
We have to know in advance who the recipient is.
If we know that we are going to want to filter on the recipient of the message and the original
sender knows this, they will place that in the topics itself so that we can actually
filter for these particular kinds of messages.
Intrinsically, the way that we receive messages are through the topics.
They're not through the from the to the from the to are essentially just the keys that
we are signing with or encrypting with.
There's a quick example.
In this example, we're creating an identity.
We're posting a message.
The message is going to be from our identity.
We are actually being honest about it.
Here we are.
The topic in this case is just an application name.
The payload is just a message saying, you know, hi, what's your name.
We're also going to have this watch here which is watching for these kinds of messages.
It's watching for this broadcast message.
I identified via the fact it's actually this application.
When we find this, what we're going to do is just log to the console.
We found someone who's asking us what our name is.
On the other side, we would watch this broadcast and potentially we could reply to it.
We would check to make sure it's not us who is asking for people's names.
Assuming it's not, then we're going to simply form a new message back to them.
We're going to sign it from ourselves.
We're going to use a two in this case.
We're going to say who we want the message to arrive at.
It's not a broadcast.
We're going to identify it with our topics.
We're also going to identify ourselves as one of the topics.
We're going to put our identity in there.
In terms of where the protocol is going, one of the things we're going to move into soon.
It's a plausible deniability of the authoring, which is essentially a case of having a future
-- the ability to have future people looking at messages, not be able to be determined
that it was actually us who sent the message.
But of course, at the time, there will be cryptographic certainty that it was us.
And modeling on precisely how scalable this approach is and what the trade-off is going
to be precisely between efficiency and privacy.
So how much time you'll have?
Ten more minutes, right?
Okay.
Let's see if I can give a quick demo.
How do I get rid of that?
Escape?
What happened there?
There's some reason that my -- there we go.
Okay.
This is our zero.
It's actually running a whisper node.
Here is a console.
So I'm first going to set up a filter.
So this is going to filter messages that are incoming.
You probably can't see that.
Maybe you can.
It's pretty short.
Basically, I've got a topic set.
The topic set is DevCon.
And that's the only thing that's in there.
So it's just filtering on the entire whisper system for all messages that have a topic
of DevCon.
And when it finds it, it's going to print something out for the console.
It's going to put out the found message, and then the payload, and then whoever it's
from.
Okay.
So that's created that filter.
And the next thing I'm going to do -- and this could be done on anyone's computer, but it's
going to be done online because I've only got one here.
And this is going to post the message.
So the message is posting.
It is a message whose topics are DevCon.
So the first thing can find it.
And the payload is going to be world.
There we are.
And there's a time to live, which is a minute.
Which is a minute.
And what we see is that found message.
Found message, world.
And it's from -- it's actually from the null address.
The null address just means that it was not actually signed by anybody, so we don't actually
know who it's from.
Okay.
Pretty simple.
Next thing.
Let's create an identity.
There's an identity.
That's our key.
So this is actually just an ECDSA public key that it's returned.
The actual private key is managed internally in our letter zero.
And what I'm going to do is just send that exact same message.
But I'm sending it -- actually, you know what, I'm going to change the payload so it can
tell the difference.
This is going to be hello.
The important thing is that I'm sending it from that identity.
There it is.
From ID.
Found message.
There's our new payload.
And yes, we know now that it's coming from that particular thing.
Right?
Okay.
We know that because it's actually been signed.
So it's not just some insecure sort of thing attached to it.
It's a proper signature.
Now then.
We're going to have another identity.
This is my identity.
So it's GAV.
GAV is equally a new identity.
There's my identity.
There's my identity.
And I'm going to set up a new filter.
This one's just going to filter for messages from -- with the topic, dev con gav.
Right?
Now we have to tell it actually up front that it needs to decrypt with my key.
This is to avoid having any additional metadata in the message body itself.
So we're saying all messages of topic dev con gav are actually going to be sent to me.
Now we're going to set up a watch for that and say it's going to print a message found
message to gav with a payload.
And then it's also going to tell us who it's from.
So I do that.
And of course nothing comes back because no messages have been sent yet.
But here is a post.
So we're going to post using the dev con gav topic.
And the payload there is -- let's change the payload.
Make it something interesting.
Hello.
Gav was the end.
From our original identity, xc b 4 d, blah blah blah.
But this one is to gav.
Right?
And -- okay.
Did I -- oh, yeah.
That's used double quotes instead.
And there we go.
Found message to gav.
Hello, gav.
And it's sent from that particular identity.
Yeah.
So that's a -- it's super simple.
Payload can be whatever you want it to be.
So, you know, in principle, byte data, send images around, whatever it will be.
Probably it's going to be mostly ASCII with a few hashes.
And the hashes would then lead on to some of the system's publication,
IPFS, whatever.
The topics, there can be an arbitrary number of topics.
The topics can be anded or all together so that we can say, right, it's got to contain
one of these two topics in the first place, one of these five topics in the
second place, and the third place must be this topic.
That all works fine.
And yeah, obviously the time to live.
I haven't bothered doing anything with the proof of work priority stuff, but the
principle is there and it works in practice.
This is proof POC3.
This is in the CPP code base.
I understand it is being currently implemented in the Go code base.
I think it goes up to POC2 at the moment.
And there's substantial interest in the other code bases for putting all this stuff in.
Yeah, if you want to contribute and help develop this, then get in touch.
And otherwise, thank you.
Any questions?

>> Two questions.
One question?
>> Any questions?
>> So two days ago we discussed that one paradigm of building scalable DAPs is
creating sophisticated state channels.
And I'm wondering whether WISPR is the right protocol to distribute transactions that
happen on those state channels.
Is WISPR suitable for that?
>> Yeah, so this is -- this is actually something that I would like to say.
I think with blocks and obviously the result was talking about before, the various bits
of data regarding the blockchain, this is all static data and fits well into the
IPFS swarm sort of paradigm.
Transactions definitely are much more ephemeral data that float around, generally have
broadcast semantics potentially exist within different networks, maybe private sub-networks.
So yeah, WISPR would work particularly well and it would be really cool if we can make
the transaction publication stuff actually be just an application that sits on top of
WISPR.
Yeah, definitely.
